newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait shares rise on thinner volumes in the week.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait shares rise on thinner volumes in the week.

text.p: Shares rose on the Kuwait Stock Exchange in the week to Wednesday with the index closing 1.5 percent higher at 1,610.2 points.
The official index rose 24.1 points or 1.5 percent with gains leading losses 30-12. Eight stocks were unchanged.
Daily average volume fell 22.9 percent to 97.8 million shares, with a total volume for the week of 489 million shares.
"As you see prices rose, the market is strong. The fall in volume is only normal" after weeks of active trading, said Khaled al-Saleh chairman of Gulf Brokerage Company said.
"There are many reasons to make the market strong. Mid-year results of listed companies were good and there is a big capital flow into the country," said Saleh.
Total value traded reached 87.7 million dinars ($293 million) in the week, firming 25.2 percent on a daily average basis of 17.5 million dinars.
Contracts rose seven percent to an average of 1,115 a day.
"Expectations are also positive about firms' performance in the third quarter," said Saleh al-Salami, local shares portfolio manager at the Kuwait International Investment Company.

Dealers expected the market to be more active after a September deadline for the payment of a bad debt installment by private sector firms and investors. The total debt owed to the state amounts to about $20 billion.
"The payment will give a boost of confidence to the market that there will be no share dumping," a dealer said.
The most active stocks during the week were Commercial Bank, Burgan Bank, Investment Projects, United Realty, Pearl of Kuwait Real Estate and Fujairah Cement.
Banks were the most active sector by value with 28.9 percent, followed by property with 27.4 percent and foreign firms with 21.7 percent.
Trading in shares of non-Kuwaiti firms listed on the exchange was the most active by volume with 32.5 percent. The property sector came second with 32 percent and banks were third with 19.7 percent.
